These constitute the most amusing portion of the work, and, if faithfully narratcd, the most important, as given on the authority of one who was present at the time.

Of the different forms in which anecdotos appear in his account may be mentioned that of Philip Augustus throwing himself for sorrow into Geoffrcy's grave3 the dream of the Prior of Dunstablc, with the warning given to William II.; the last interview between Louis and the King of England.

To these circumstances, which give the work no slight value and interest, we may add the fact of its being the author's matured production, begun with his earliest, and finished with the last. To this work he refers more frequently than to any other of his numerous writings, as one on which he had bestowed the greatest pains, and used the utmost care in ascertaining the truth severely. Thus in one of his latest productions he says of it:— “Dial09u8 autem praesenS, una eum libello (le Principis “ Institutione toties promisso, diu nimirum valde diligenter “ atque latenter hyemalibus lucubrationibus crebris, juxta “veritatem historicam, et quae veris parcere non novit “severitatem elaborato, ideoque tam sero prodire in ‘⁶ publicum et proferre caput denique vix auso, tanquam “anno aetatis meac septuagesimo.’'-—De Jure Mencv.
